content: The Act titled "Low-Income Housing Preservation Act of 1993" establishes a 15-year recovery period. The Act establishes a 15-year recovery period for residential rental properties in qualified low-income housing projects. For tax purposes, a qualified low-income housing project is defined as residential rental property where at least 50% of the units are occupied by individuals with incomes below 80% of the area median income at the time of initial occupancy. A qualified low-income housing project must meet certain criteria such as having units occupied by individuals with incomes below 80% of the area median income, being placed in service at least 10 years before acquisition, being substantially rehabilitated, and potentially receiving rental assistance under section 8 of the United States Housing Act of 1937. The taxpayer must have acquired their interest in the project by purchase, and the project must not have been previously placed in service by the taxpayer or any related person. Additionally, a project cannot be considered a qualified low-income housing project if any benefits are claimed under section 42 for the same project.
